description: A tabletop skirmish warband game, 18+ mature content, a player versus player game, average game duration 2 hours, an out of the box game.

Stalingrad Advance to the Volga, 1942 puts the player in charge of the attacking and far more mobile German side while the game system handles the defending and largely static Soviet side. No two games will ever be the same. Each turn represents new and unique challenges for the player in the form of random events, uncertain supply deliveries and unknown Soviet area strength and defensive strategies.

Story
The dumplings made by the master are excellent. You are in charge of skewering as an apprentice! Make beautiful skewered dumplings and earn praise from your master!

Game Outline
(1) Preparation
Players place the first two dumpling cards (hereafter referred to as “cards”) in their work area.

(2) Round
Players gain one card per round and place it in their work area.
After 6 rounds, 8 cards are finally placed on the work area so that the number of dumplings is 4 x 5 (regardless of the length or width).

(3) Skewering
Players skewer 3 or 4 connected dumplings in their work area to make dumplings.

(4) Score calculation
The scores of the skewered dumplings are added up for each player. The player with the highest score is the winner of the game.

The Great Horse Knowledge game Equi Quiz is a board game for everyone who loves horses.
The more you know about these noble animals, the faster you can build your dream stable.
The board game is for all horse lovers from 12 years old. You play the game with 2 to 4 people.
It is also possible to play with several people, but then teams must be made.
The questions are divided into 6 different categories:
Behaviour, Anatomy, Sports & Recreation, Nutrition & Health, Grooming & Equipment, and Breeds & History.
There are 60 different questions per category – so 360 in total.

Answer a question each turn. You can earn victory points by answering the question correctly. With these profit points you buy dream stable parts. There are 7 different dream stable parts that must be collected by each player. The first player to collect all 7 different dream stable parts wins the game.

Along the way you will face windfalls and obstacles, just like in real life.
You will come across “The masked horse” and “The prince on the horse”. If you end up on “The Horse Stable” then parts can be exchanged. But you know the well-known proverb: “Exchanging leads to crying”. Who knows, you might even laugh! Be surprised.

It doesn't matter if you are a professional or a hobby rider, this horse knowledge board game is challenging for all horse lovers of all levels.
The playing time is between 30 and 60 minutes.
Equi Quiz is a true must-have for anyone who loves horses!

-translated from the publisher site'

63 is a two or three-player map-based strategy game themed around the competing ideologies in Welsh politics after 1963.  Players represent the Welsh national movement, the left or socialist movement, or British unionism.  The Liberal Party is represented as a 'non-human player' who any player can choose to play as, instead of as themselves, during their turn.

The aim of the game is to place all pieces held in a player's hand onto the board, with the pieces representing bases on key locations in Wales.

Play is turn-based, with fixed and visible movement abilities and options (which include base-building, grid movement and rail movement), and no chance mechanisms at all. There is no player elimination.  As well as outright victory, two types of draws can end the game - one with all the human players losing.

—description from the designer

This fun family board game will teach the entire family entrepreneurial skills! Children will comprehend how companies operate. They will understand how companies make money and why some companies are more, and others less successful.

Firma Kids is the ideal tool for quality and pleasant socializing. While your child runs his or her first imaginary company, you will proudly watch him or her acquire knowledge that he or she will possess for the rest of his or her life. Firma Kids is a great choice which will give your child abundance of knowledge that he or she can use throughout his or her life.

AWAY TEAM: The Voyages of the Pandora is a game of exploring alien worlds in distant star systems. You command the Pandora, an interstellar survey ship on its voyages of discovery. Each voyage sends Pandora to a different star system where you assemble away teams from the ship’s crew and equipment to explore planets, moons and other sites of interest, with the following directives:
- Locate exo-life forms, and document their physiology and behavior;
- Collect exo-DNA, vital to genetic science and human adaptation to life in the stars;
- Identify and survey environments suitable for human settlement and development;
- Search for intelligent life and alien cultures; and if found, establish contact with goodwill;
- Don’t get killed.

AWAY TEAM has three modes of play.
- The solitaire campaign game, provides an epic inter-connected narrative experience for one player across seven star systems; providing over 80 hours of play time, exploration, and plot-twists.
- The solitaire star system game provides one player with a repeatable play experience commanding one Pandora voyage to a single star system. You set the experience level of your crew and the danger level of each voyage.
- The 2-player game puts players in command of competing away teams from Pandora in a voyage to a single star system, also a repeatable play experience.

Forty years ago, John Butterfield designed The Voyage of the BSM Pandora, the ground-breaking solitaire paragraph-driven game for SPI. Now John takes his branching narrative game concept into a new dimension with Away Team: The Voyages of the Pandora.

-description from publisher
In Fairy Concerto, players vie for the best orchestra for their concert. Players will draft fairies to meet orchestra requirements. Players can also earn points from set collecting.

Each player chooses a paragon and takes their deck of 7 unique cards. Every turn, players choose a card from their hand and play them simultaneously. Both cards are revealed and then characters either take damage, have their card canceled and sent back to their hand, or are defeated. Play the right card at the right time and have a strong read of your opponent's intentions to win!

This box features 8 paragons from the Acquisitions Incorporated universe and two dials to track health and energy.

-description from the publisher

Object of game: Play beast and phenomena cards in turn to win gems.    Win gems by playing high-ranking beasts that cannot be defeated by another player or by playing the same value beast to trigger a war. Be the first player to earn enough gems to win the game.

Cards: There are 72 unique beasts with 6 unique beasts of the same value with varying single or double elements and 48 phenomena cards that are either +1 or -1 modifiers for two, three or four elements.

Gameplay: The first beast card played can be any value and is called the current beast. Play moves clockwise to the next player attempting to beat the current beast card.  The current player must play only one beast card that is of equal or higher value than the current beast.  Phenomena can only be played on your turn and can act on any individual beast; you can play as many phenomena as you wish. There is only one active beast at a time, once a beast is beaten it can be discarded with all the phenomena attached to that beast.  The round will continue until all players cannot beat the current beast.  Ties will result in a war occurs.
End of Game - If at any time during the game the draw pile has been exhausted just re-shuffle the discard pile.  Game ends once one player reaches 10 or greater gems for 2 players.
3 players – 9 gems
4 players – 8 gems
5 players – 7 gems
6 players – 6 gems

—description from the designer

This original game from Japanese lands swells the catalogs of the murder mystery genre, increasingly widespread in the international recreational arena.

What is a murder mystery?
In this deductive genre, each player plays the role of a character with the dual purpose of clarifying a mystery and simultaneously achieving their own goals. The investigation, the negotiations with the rest of the cast and the exchange of information are fundamental pieces to solve the crime, but we must not forget that the murderer is one of you. You cannot believe everything they tell you, but neither can you win without trusting someone ... Enjoy this unique experience that, although used only once, will leave you wanting more.

England, late 16th century. A man is found dead in a town in the English countryside, apparently after his executioner plunged his head into the river that runs next to the inn where he was staying. The guests, the white witch so beloved in the municipality and the employees of the establishment themselves look at each other suspiciously trying to identify the culprit.

DIFFERO is a game for two players. It is played with a hexagonal board and 13 black and white pieces each.

In this game, you win by calculating the difference in strength between your side and the enemy side, and by supporting your own side or blocking the opponent’s side to reach the goal.

While steadily advancing your own piece, you often find yourself unable to stop the opponent’s pieces that is closing in. This is a fun abstract game with simple rules and thrills.

Components

     13 white and 13 black pieces each
     Hexagonal board with 5 on a side


End condition

     You win when one of your piece reach the goal.
     You lose if you cannot move any of your pieces in your turn.


Preparation

     Place pieces in predetermined positions.
     Choose your own color. White is the first turn.


Play procedure
On your turn, you moves only one of your pieces according to the following rules

     The piece moves on a line. The piece may jump over any number of pieces at once, either your own and your opponent’s.
     The number of steps to move the piece is always (number of your pieces) − (number of your opponent’s pieces) on the line to be moved. If this value is less than or equal to 0, the piece cannot move on the line.
     You cannot move the piece off the board or into a place already occupied by another piece. Also, you cannot move the piece into the opponent’s goal.


—description from the designer

Nimmerlichtern is a cooperative board game for up to 4 players, throwing roleplay, area-control and fortress building mechanics into the mix. Each player takes over one kid out of a ragtag group of survivors and enters the world of a stodgy 90s suburb - where kids' dreams quite literally become reality. The goal is to fight back the monsters borne from the children's own subconsciousness, before the horde of evil dreams swallows the town completely.

To make matters worse, each kid is haunted by their very own primal fear, drafted randomly at the games' beginning out of a pool of six: The fears of loneliness, illness, pain, darkness, deceipt and decay. Starting as mere forebodings, these Grand Nightmares grow stronger and gain abilities at the end of each round, the pace heavily depends on the decisions of the players. At some point the primal fears manifest themselves and enter the game board to lead their minions against the last remaining refuge: the childrens' headquarters in the attic of an empty house. A game is lost once a Grand Nightmare and its pack reaches the headquarters and the subsequent battle is lost by the players.

To avoid that outcome, the players must use their rounds – each representing a day, from dawn to dusk - to break the curse cast upon their formerly cozy town. Gather resources, build weapons, craft fortifications and barricades and banish the monsters back to the realm of nightmares where they belong.

But foremost, they've got to learn to harness the force of dreams to their advantage: At the beginning of each round –in the morning – every player draws a card from their unique deck of dream cards, containing good dreams, bad dreams, dreams that affect the game board itself and also continuous dreams that can be collected in order to unleash unparalleled powers. Dream diaries, night time seances, REM manipulators and other bizarre objects can be used to get the decks under control – to a point, because, if Nimmerlichtern teaches you one thing, it's that the force of dreams is something to be reckoned with.

So be careful what you wish for: Your dreams just might come true.

—description from the publisher

The witty and clever game of headlines! This fun multi-player party game is perfect for family game night, or a night-in with your friends.

Think of entertaining captions that would best suit the photos. Let your peers decide who produced the best one! The player with the most brilliant one-liners, wins!

—description from the publisher

Surprise Ending simulates a murder investigation. After a party in a mansion, one character turns up dead. Everyone at the table is a suspect, and the incompetent police does not care whether they catch the murderer, as long as they can arrest someone.

The game consists entirely of cards. Each player gets a character card and a character trait card. One of the unused characters is flipped open - that's the murder victim. Some details about the victim and the way they were murdered are also randomly assigned. Each player has four face-down "exposed" cards in front of them. On a turn, flip one card in front of another player open. This reveals some information about that player which is somehow suspicious. The entire group now has 30 seconds to discuss why this player is clearly the murderer. Then the accused player has 30 seconds to defend themselves. Afterwards, they flip another player's card up, etc. Once everyone was exposed once, more information about the victim is revealed, and another round starts (with 3 players, a third round as well). 
Afterwards, everyone points their finger at the most suspicious player at the table. The player(s) with the most fingers pointing at them will be arrested, draw an ending card and read out the ending of the story. 
Players who pointed at an arrested player and were not arrested themselves, win the game.

EHCG is mainly deck construction, dice rolling and role playing strategy game set in world of ice hockey.

Your task as a manager of ice hockey club is to pick your coach and lineup of 12 players, assign the role for each player, choose the tactics, and lead your team to the victory.

Each player chooses unique situational cards, which can be used throughout the game. During the match, you have to guide your players in different situations from the faceoff to shot. Significant part of the game are 1v1 battles of players, where your preparation and skill can truly shine. If you are successful, you will gain many bonuses and you can affect the strategy of both teams. Additionally, as the manager, you have many options in every situation to change the course of the match and turn the result in your favor.

EHCG is game for 2 players, who can battle over and over again in a single match. However, it contains setup of 20 teams, therefore it offers option to integrate up to 20 people, who can compete in different modes such as tournament mode or season mode.

Each player is dealt a stockpile of 15 cards. The winner will be whoever manages to empty their stockpile first. Cards are played onto four shared building piles in numerical sequence from 1 to 12. On each turn, a player draws until they have five cards in their hand, and then plays cards from: their hand, a top card of their discard piles, or their stockpile, or they can use a coin in place of a card, or they can use a coin to take a card from their opponents stock pile or discard pile. Some cards require using coins to pay a toll. At the end of their turn, a player must discard onto one of their four personal discard piles. Strategy involves the organizing of cards into the discard piles and using your coins wisely, care in not setting up the next players for good plays, knowing when to play from which option, and especially the timing of playing a valuable "Skip-Bo" wildcard. Players still try and get rid of all the cards from their Stock Pile, but the coins can be used to help fill in a sequence of cards or even to buy a card from another player's Discard Pile or Stock Pile!

DUEL BOY is a trading card game with unique seven-card packs. The game was first distributed at the 2022 Fall Tokyo Game Market. The packs include seven cards for playing the game, one divider card, and a sticker the owner can wear to help find opponents to play the game.

The game was designed to be played while standing (for instance, while in line to buy a game) and does not require a table. After a match, the players swap two cards, with each player leaving with five cards they entered the game with and two of their opponent's cards.

After an initial shuffle of cards, a player has one chance to reshuffle, but otherwise must play their hand as it has been drawn. A game is made up of several rounds, and the first player to win three hands or cause their opponent to not be able to play a card on their first turn of a hand wins the game.

Players can play cards only from the rightmost end of their hand and must pay the cost of cards with the cards from the left end of their hand. Once per hand, a player can put the cards from their discard pile on the bottom of the deck — in the exact order they were discarded.

A soccer game released by Bandai in the Soccer Joy series.

The game use action cards to move a 6 players team on the soccer board and to simulate tackle and shoot, specific event cards and dice.

Dreamworld is a lightweight card game for 2–4 players that plays in 20–30 minutes. It is designed by Jonny Pac, co-designer of Unconscious Mind and the lead developer for Fantasia Games.

As a follower of Freud’s theories of the unconscious mind, your goal is to help suffering people recover from their psychological traumas. You can foster each client’s healing potential by interpreting the symbolism of their dreams.

At the start of a round, each player chooses a dream card and simultaneously reveals it. Next, you’ll arrange the cards numerically beside the current client. The difference between your card’s number and the next limits how many treatment tokens you may score: the bigger the gap, the better. If you’re the first to complete all your tokens, it proves your treatments were the most effective—making you Freud’s most formidable contemporary.

—description from the publisher

Totem is one of the world's easiest and quickest games to learn; as simple as 'Tic-Tac-Toe' (Tic-Tac-Totem)!

—description from the rulebook

Basically, this game is similar to Connect 4, except the board is round and will rotate so the players can easily see the whole playing area.  The rulebook also gives unique names to the "traps" players can use in the game to set up a winning condition...such as "Steeple, Line-Ladder and Overlap."

The final sentence in the rulebook description of the game says "if Tic-Tac-Toe and Chess had an offspring, it would be TOTEM!"

—user summary

Starting from a small town, will you be able to develop your civilization with constructions and discoveries until you get to build the Statue of Liberty ?

During the game you will have to manage your resources to build and upgrade your villages, you will have to advance your civilization, sometimes you will have to fight to attack the enemy or defend yourself.

—description from the designer

The bang quiz from the makers of Ik hou van Holland. Play the nerve-wracking question game from Ik hou van Holland. Answer the questions correctly and pass the gift. But beware, if you don't know an answer, are you too slow? Then the gift might explode in your hands... BOOM!

—description from the publisher

Something strange has been happening in the Manor lately. Black feathers appeared all around the Manor, seemingly out of nowhere. Members of the Family started to act out of character and some have died under mysterious circumstances. But these are no accidents - someone is pulling the strings behind the scenes and he needs to be stopped as soon as possible. Can the surviving members of the Family find and kill him before it’s too late?

Raven Manor is a social deduction party game with stunning dark graphics, inspired by Sin City comics and with easy-to-learn rules that lead to deep gameplay.

One of you will play as the Raven. The rest will take on the role of the Family. As the Raven, your goal is to possess or kill the other players. As the Family, you must use your wits and deduction skills to uncover the Raven's identity and eliminate them before it's too late. Death doesn’t stop you from enjoying the game. If you’re killed, you’re playing just as before, but with a restriction - from now on you can’t kill anyone else. No more waiting for other players to finish the game!

Use deduction, lie, bluff and simply have a good time with your friends. Will you be able to catch the Raven?

The Airport board game is a challenging family board game where each player operates a delivery company which transports goods for customers from one city to another via airplanes. Players play cards from their hands to finish the delivery job, but each city can be occupied only by one player, so plan your routes carefully!

A ghostly pirate-themed solo trick-taking card game where you play against two A.I. opponents (ghost crew) vying to score more card points than the combined scores of the crew. Special cards include Rat cards that infest your hand eating your highest cards, and Pirate cards that have two suits and win almost any trick. To win the game, take at least 5 of the 9 gems before the crew take 5. Each round you bet on the number of gems you are attempting to take. The Pirate cards contain images of famous female Pirates throughout history, including Ching Shih, Awilda, Sayyida al Hurra, Anne Bonny, and Mary Read.

-description from designer

The Mexican Revolution that began in 1910 with the overthrow of dictator Porfirio Diaz degenerated into civil war following the assassination of President Francisco Madero. By end of 1915 the forces of President Carranza were arrayed against a variety of leaders supporting either themselves or General Victoriano Huerta. Pancho Villa, commander of the Mexican Army del Norte, at first supported Carranza, but then went rogue after the US Government recognized Carranza’s government. Historians still debate Villa’s reasons, but in early March 1916 he decided to enter the US and raid the town of Columbus, New Mexico. Although the town was where the 13th Regiment US Cavalry was garrisoned, he knew most of the troopers were scattered along the border. Believing the town was only weakly guarded, his force of just under 500 men were to steal arms, provisions and horses while also wreaking as much havoc as possible. Such a raid he believed could galvanize the US government into a retaliatory strike that would drag Carranza’s government into a war with the US it could not win, or a humiliating capitulation that would outrage the Mexican people. Either way, Villa reasoned, it would mean the downfall of Carranza.

Villa’s Vengeance is an introductory level wargame simulation portraying the March 9, 1916 raid on Columbus, New Mexico. Players are cast in the roles of Villa’s raiding force and the defending US regular and militia forces.

—description from the publisher

The GOTHIES Deckbuilding Game is set in the mythical Underworld of Xibalba where players enter the underworld as Dreamers, or Streya, where they can play head-to-head with the goal of waking the other player up in order to win the game.

The game can also be played in a solitaire or cooperative mode where the players try and defend the well of Ceiba, or the gateway from the underworld to the real world, from attack by the monsters sent by the God of the Well. The God, who is no longer satisfied with the underworld, wants to send his monsters to the real world to expand his power.

The Players begin the game with 45 Timestones (life total) 10 starter cards, 6 of which grant seed power (purchase new cards) and 4 have song power (attack). As players buy GOTHIE (creature) cards and Land (shield) cards from the Mercado (tableau) they add them to their decks, where they can achieve synergy bonuses based on the heart rune of the cards played. The game plays similarly to other head-to-head deckbuilders in this respect, but can be converted to play cooperatively using the same deckbuilding mechanics.

In the coop mode, this plays very similar to a tower defense game like Castle Panic, but the threats all come from a single direction, and the monsters can attack the well and "possess" the GOTHIES that the players have in their played card zone. This ups the difficulty because the players' former GOTHIE cards now fight against them until they are restored.

The game is for 2 players, and can be expanded to 4 with two sets. The game comes with 162 cards and counters to track timestones.

-description from publisher

You’re a 56k Samurai, a Console Cowboy, a Digital Hired Gun in the data wars. Your employer needs you to run a sabotage mission: break into Oni Corp. servers and install a virus. Are you savvy enough to do the job and get paid or will your location get traced and your door kicked in by corporate security?

---

56k samurai is a solo game Print and Play card game which lasts between 10 to 20 minutes per game. During the game, the player will manipulate their console, a set of 6 cards laid side by side. The player manipulates cards by executing their commands attempting to rotate all 18 cards to their cracked state to win. Each card will have a command at the top. To execute a card, slide it up slightly to indicate it’s been executed. Then perform the command. Each of these commands must be executed to move on but the order they’re executed in makes all the difference.

All even numbered cards have alarms on them which will alert security personnel to your intrusion. Too many alarms at a time and you’ll be traced. Then it’s game over, man. Game over.

-description from designer

Fluxx is a card game in which the cards themselves determine the current rules of the game. By playing cards, you change numerous aspects of the game: how to draw cards, how to play cards, and even how to win.

At the start of the game, each player holds three cards and on a turn a player draws one card, then plays one card. By playing cards, you can put new rules into play that change numerous aspects of the game: how many cards to draw or play, how many cards you can hold in hand or keep on the table in front of you, and (most importantly) how to win the game.

Across America Fluxx uses the basic gameplay of Fluxx, but now you're traveling across the United States of America to check out famous landmarks and national parks, from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Statue of Liberty, including the Grand Canyon, Hollywood, Cape Canaveral, Devil's Tower, the monuments of DC, and, of course, amusement parks. Across America Fluxx also includes a few special twists, including the new rule "Play All Day" and an action called "Route 66".

Each round in Demigods, each player trains a hero by taking a demigod card and artifact card at random from the center of the table and pairing them together. The demigod cards feature a strength value and possibly symbols, while the artifact cards (possibly) modify the value of the paired demigod card in some way, with the maximum value for any combination being 30.

A starting pot of 1 Aischune (meaning "dishonor") is created, then in turn players take one of three actions:


     Adding more Aischune to the pot up to a maximum of 10.
     Knocking on the table to stay in without raising.
     Discarding their cards to fold the hand, with the first folder gaining 3 Aischune and each other folder gaining 2 Aischune.


Once the maximum pot has been reached or all players have passed, players reveal their totals, with the weakest player "winning" the pot. In ties, the pot is split between those with the lowest score.

Continue playing rounds until someone has collected at least 30 Aischune at which time the game ends and whoever has the fewest Aischune wins. In the event of a tie, keep playing rounds until one player has the lowest score.

The game has been designed as a tribute for the centenary of the discovery...
One of the most important discoveries in modern archeology occurred on November 26, 1922, when the tomb of Pharaoh Tutankhamun, from the 18th dynasty, was found. After cataloging all the treasures in the chambers, Carter arrived at the royal chamber where the pharaoh's sarcophagus had rested for three thousand years. From then on, people who had visited the tomb began to die, this fact is popularly known as the Pharaoh's curse.
The objective of the game is to be the player with the most valuable collection of treasures (most points) extracted from Tutankhamen's tomb and at the same time not to be the player who dies from the effect of the pharaoh's curse.

—description from the designer

Uno de los hallazgos más importantes de la arqueología moderna se produjo el 26 de noviembre de 1922, cuando se encontró la tumba del faraón Tutankamón, de la dinastía XVIII. Después de catalogar todos los tesoros de las cámaras, Carter llegó a la cámara real donde descansaba el sarcófago del faraón desde hacía tres mil años. A partir de entonces empezaron a morir personas que habían visitado la tumba, este hecho es conocido popularmente como la maldición del faraón. 
El objetivo del juego es ser el jugador con la colección de tesoros más valiosa (más puntos) extraída de la tumba de Tutankamón y a la vez no ser el jugador que muera por efecto de la maldición del faraón.

—description from the designer (Spanish)

It is the age of sail. Distant empires, hungry for the wealth and resources of the New World, have bankrolled colonies on these distant shores. Now, as ancient grudges and rivalries reignite, piracy and privateering are expanding from single-ship engagement into small flotillas commanded by young commodores. Their goal: take the seas back for their home nations, and perhaps win more than a little gold in the process…

Privateer is the first title in the Articles of War series. It is a fast-paced, hex-based naval engagement where 2 to 6 players use a combination of sailing, cannon-fire, and the occasional boarding action to sink or capture the ships belonging to their opponents. For each enemy ship dispatched, a gold doubloon is awarded to the attacker with ultimate victory going to whichever player has the most gold at the end of the game.

The central mechanic of AoW: Privateer is a special dice economy, where the active player rolls a combination of sail and cannonball dice based on the number of ships they have active and their strategic preferences. After rolling, they spend these dice one-by-one in order to maneuver their ships into position and target their cannons to eliminate enemies. Islands and reefs, placed by the players during setup, provide a limitless variety of map arrangements.

—description from the publisher

There is a tribe of people that can communicate with animals (Wanyama). You, the player, have the ability to borrow the animals’ powers. There is a law in this tribe, that the leader’s ability to communicate with the animals is extraordinary.

In this game, you will compete with other players to become the leader of the tribe. The object of the game is to reach the goal with the help of the Wanyama.

This game is played by gaining points as you draw cards and play them against your opponents, you can play this game in a short time with a steady rhythm.

—description from the designer

Oh dear, a thick rain cloud is gathering over the farm, but the animals are still in the pasture! Together, the children try to get the animals into the barn by rolling the dice before the rain cloud is full of drops. Depending on the game variant, the die shows either the shape or the color of the animal that may be placed in the barn or a drop of water (blue colour) that moves into the cloud.
All players win or lose together against the rain cloud and thus experience an intensive "we-feeling". In addition to the differentiation of shapes and colors, the game also promotes concentration, initial understanding of rules, fine motor skills and language development.

A spinner decides if the active player is asked a question or if he has to choose 1 of 4 characteristics. If the characteristics are positive, the chosen one should apply best to him. If they are negative, he chooses the one whom he disagrees the most with. 
Before the active player reveals his decision, all other players guess secretly the answer of the active player and may bid in addition with chips. Then the answers are revealed. The guessing players receive chips, if they guessed correctly. The active player receive as many chips as the most successful guesser. If nobody guessed correctly, he may lose chips. The player with the most chips wins.

—user summary

Oda Nobunaga once said that he would hunt his enemies down "on every hill and valley." That term, in Japanese, is "yama yama tani tani".

In Yama Yama Tani Tani 2 or 4 players choose from among 6 different Chinese warlords of the Three Kingdoms era or from among 6 different Japanese daimyo of the Warring States period to battle each other in a no-luck, no-dice faceoff for supremacy in their respective countries.

Each leader comes with his 9 most trusted generals and must be divided into two armies of five units each. Players select their first 5-man army for the first battle, and assign each general a troop type based on that general's allowances and the strategic advantages that player wants to pursue. Then each player assigns those units to the first battlefield.

Generals move about the battlefield, attacking enemy generals, but with a twist. The skills that each general has allow him to do more than just make basic attacks. They allow him to both manipulate the enemy units and his own to his advantage, but, more importantly, the correct use of a skill can trigger another friendly general to use one of his skills, adding more damage to the attack. That general's use of a skill could trigger another, an so on. The real strategy is trying to make the most of your generals' skills and build wildly powerful combos of attacks on the battlefield to destroy your opponent's army.

After each battle, the winning player gains Mandate according to the number of his generals still alive. After 6 battles, if one player has more Mandate, that player is the winner. If players are tied, there will be a 7th and final battle, using all 10 of those players' generals, to determine the victor.

-description from designer

UNknown SUBject is a fast-paced social deduction game based on the hit TV show Criminal Minds! Play as familiar FBI Behavioral Analysis Unit Agents to identify the killer in your midst, or work against the goals of the BAU to get away with your crimes and escape! Investigate, use the profile, and accuse your fellow players to come out on top!


    FAST & EASY—The average game takes about 20 minutes and once you get started it's easy to play over and over again!
    FAN-FAVORITE—UNknown SUBject is full of nods to Criminal Minds, from the characters to the profile you build, with simple enough gameplay for fans to play alongside those unfamiliar with the show!
    NEW GAME EVERY TIME—With different characters and different roles for each game you play, no two playthroughs are exactly alike!


SOCIAL DEDUCTION—Use your knowledge of your fellow players to try and uncover the Unsub or convince the group of your innocence!

    BE THE CHARACTERS—The game includes J.J., Garcia, Morgan, Reid, and Rossi alongside the Eyewitness and Unsubs! 


—description from the publisher

Defeat all of your rivals to be the last one standing! But be careful. Don't let them bring your guard down and keep your resistances at full health, as they are the only things, that save you from the ongoing mana storm!

Make the right decisions, think about who you can backstab the easiest and who you need to make an alliance with until the very end, as you try to survive the unnatural storm you and your rivals were trapped in!

—description from the designer

Campsite has players competing for the best camping spot. Play cards on top of each other to link elements like forests, mountains, and camping trails together to score the most points.

A clever card-based "tile" laying game that focus on maximizing your limited space!

Luck and strategy combine in the great outdoors (no actual camping required). Includes 72 cards 42 tokens, scorepad, and pencil.

—description from the publisher

Time to go back to Monster School! All pupils are ready to start working again. They have been asked to draw the scariest monster of the school to become the Big Bad Monster!

Every turn, each player picks one of the available dice, then draw the matching feature on their sheet, adding an eye, tooth, leg, arm, horn or accessory to their Monster.

When a Monster gets 2, 3 or 5 features of the same type, its owner can choose to add the matching Scare token to their track on the Scare-o-Meter. But beware: each token is unique and a player can pick only one for each feature!

The goal of the game is have your Scare-O-meter full with Scare tokens before the other players do. To be the first to fill your Scare-o-Meter, you will need to watch your opponents closely and figure out if you can push your luck, or if you should rather play it safe.

-description from publisher

A talking electronic plush sloth acts as the timer, judge and prop in this two team charades type game.

The sloth will randomly assign one of the three super slo-mo clue categories: Sloth Charades, SL-ACTING or sloth-ercise. The active team then has 45 seconds to guess the correct clue. The player assigned to be the round actor, though, cannot move too quickly or else the sloth will get upset and buzz. Three buzzes and your turn is over.

The non-active team can steal the clue whenever it is not guessed by the active team. Guessing a clue correctly results in one point. Alternating play continues until one team has accumulated 5 points and therefore wins the game.

In NAWALLI, a creature battle card game based on Aztec mythology, you take on the role of a shapeshifting sorcerer known as a Nawalli to summon Nawals — allies such as creatures of the forest, ghosts, and monsters to battle in the arenas.

The game comes with four partially pre-built decks, representing Aztec gods from the four directions: Tezkatlipoka, Tlalok, Ehakatl, and Xipe Totek. In the main game mode, players select one deck, then draft a complementary team of creatures, items, and spells before doing battle in the arena.

Each creature you summon has unique abilities based on the twenty Aztec Daysigns, e.g., Eagle allows your creatures to fly one lane over to attack, Jaguar allows shifting one lane before attacking, and Snake allows eating defeated Nawals to absorb their powers.

Nawals can be combined together to create a hybrid creature with more health, power, and both sets of abilities. Shapeshifting a Nawal restores its life completely, so finish off your opponent's wounded creatures to avoid giving them a powerful play.

è¯æ­¦æ‹³! (Kabuken!) is a battling game with the theme of a tournament of martial artists from many different countries, fighting to decide the true success of the legendary martial art "Kabuken!". The goal of the game is to be the player with the most HP at the end of the game, after player(s) are KO'd or the draw pile has been depleted a number of times.

In this game you can either replenish your hand or play 1 of 6 types of melds to attack the opponent to your left. This in turn can be raw damage taken, defended (reduced damage), or counterattacked by the defending player. Counterattacking involves playing 1-3 specific cards which cause the next clockwise player to take damage, this in turn can be counterattacked, and so on until the player that does not counterattack takes damage (and replenishes their hand).

The advanced rules of the game include personal Character Cards that have different special abilities and Special Technique Cards that have either 1-time or passive effects.

While normally this game is only playable by 2-4 players, there are 5-7 player variant rules included which retain many of the same rules, with the addition of a first KO incentive.

The Advanced Tobruk System returns to Finland with six new scenarios and four new maps to further explore the remarkable defense of Suomi from the overwhelming might of Soviet invaders.

The scenarios include:
- Louhenjoki Loss – Louhenjoki, Finland, December 5th 1939

- Vuoksi Hold-Outs – Vuoksi River Sector, Karelian Isthmus, Finland, March 1st 1940

- Wooden Redoubts – Along Lake Suvanto and the Taipale River, east-of Rauti, Finland, December 30th 1939

- Between a Jarvi and a Hard Place – Between Lake Kuolema and Lake Muolaa, Finland, February 8th 1940

- Following Orders – Tolvajarvi, Finland, December 12th 1939

- Icy Frog-March – Near Suomussalmi, Finland, December 30th 1939

This package includes one sheet of vehicle and heavy weapons (88 counters), one sheet of personnel and support weapons (155 counters), two sheets of AFV cards, four 18' x 12" cardstock maps and the usual Battlefield Walkaround with module-specific rules.

All the combat counters required for these scenarios are included in this folio package, but players will need the ATS rulebook, play aids and standard system markers to play, plus one or more 10-sided dice.

The great savings boom has arrived!
Many people want to share a room in order to live on cheap rent.
The player acts as an intermediary for room sharing,
We will introduce rooms that can be shared with our customers.

However, the apartments we introduce can only accommodate up to three people in each room.
If you share a room with more than 4 people, the landlord will find you and you will be kicked out of the room.
Establish a room share for 3 people who can save the most rent more than other players,
Let's aim for the position of No1 intermediary!

—description from the designer

Micro Mars: 2-player PvP Edition is a fun and fast Roll&Write/Print&Play game of open space adventure where the players make decisions about how to capture more territory on the map.

To start a game, players roll 2 dice in turn. In the following, you can find the elements for the rolled values 
of the dice in the route field. Since you have two elements, you can craft a figure.

The goal of the game is to fill the space of the map with your figures. To get more points, you need to fill in more spaces in the points field. Your points per round are all the cells that you filled in the points field minus the unfilled cells on the map. A player who collects more points wins the game.

—description from the publisher

You work in a science lab and secretly build new monsters. These monsters come from peas and are called Creepeas. Create as many complete monsters as possible. But watch out! There can also be mismonsters, which will spoil the fun if you don’t complete them. Combine the funniest limbs and create your own crazy monsters! Can you build more complete monsters than your opponents? Whoever earns the most points wins this monstrously fun game!

Creepeas is a card game for 2 to 5 players, and takes about 20 minutes to complete. Combine cards together to earn points and win the game by having the most points of all players.

—description from the publisher

"Postcard Stalingrad" is a relatively fast and simple but historical 9-turn wargame about the 23Aug42-19Nov42 Battle for Stalingrad city.
12 starting units - mostly divisions - for Germans and Russians, each, with some Russian reinforcements and replacements (if they make it across the Volga) and (more) time pressure of Turn 7 withdrawal of 1 motorized and 1 panzer division to cover campaign's flanks which were becoming "worrisome." }:-)
German airpower and 1 later turn of Pioneers/Engineers bonus.  Pressed attack.
Russian east bank artillery and "hugging" tactic.  Chuikov.  Snipers Zaitsev vs. Koenig.  
Russian "No land East of the Volga" No Retreat! orders.

And anyone is free to print this or my other 5 (so far) postcard wargames off in postcard size/format only (4x6/A6 or 5x8/A5)... as long as my copyright statement and the Dedication are retained ... to mail/give to family and friends.

(Of course, for your own personal copy you will want to photocopy-enlarge the components.)

—description from the designer

Let's PLAAY Tennis is a “pro tennis toolbox” that includes several components, allowing you to dial in to the level of detail you desire. If quick play is what you’re looking for, the Tournament Mode module will let you simulate the early and middle rounds of an entire tournament in about 20 minutes, reducing the field to a handful of finalists. You can then use the “For The Set” and “No Rally” modules to resolve the remaining tournament matches in 10 to 20 minutes more.

On the other hand, if you’re looking for detail, the “point-by-point” module will let you watch the action unfold as if you were courtside, with serves, returns, difficult shots, winners, momentum and even unusual and rare results.

The “For the Set” module is the main tool in the box. It serves as a bridge between the two extremes of speed and detail. It will instantly resolve the preliminary action of a set and take you to the potential set-deciding game--one player with the opportunity to win the sixth and deciding game of the set. From there, you can get to your final result with extended drama, point-by-point, or instantly via the “No Rally” results.
